Context:
The Centre for Business programs at George Brown College are part of the School of Management and have earned international recognition from the Accreditation Council for Business Schools and Programs (ACBSP). A total of 14 diplomas, advanced diplomas, and degree programs in Accounting & Finance, HR, Management, and Marketing have been accredited. George Brown College is one of only two colleges in Ontario with ACBSP accreditation.

The college has adopted a Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) initiative, requiring students in the Centre for Business program to bring their own laptops. Open access computers are available at the Library Learning Commons, as well as equipment that can be borrowed on a short-term basis. Students interested in work experience should apply to B155, which offers on-the-job experience and field education opportunities with real-world challenges and clients.

Graduates of the program are prepared for various administrative and management positions and have found employment as assistant managers, customer service representatives, financial services representatives, project managers, project coordinators, and sales associates. To graduate from the B145 program, students must complete 36 courses: 27 mandatory courses, 6 business electives, and 3 general education electives. Depending on placement test results, students may be required to take COMM 1000 (Introduction to College Communication) or MATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) before progressing to higher-level courses.

Contact the Centre for Business for more information at business@georgebrown.ca.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business Administration Program B145 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
To graduate from the college, students are required to complete a total of 36 courses. Two courses, ATH 1027 (Business Math with Remediation) and COMM 1000, do not count toward these requirements and will incur additional charges. Students must complete three General Education courses from at least two categories: Social Sciences (GSSC), Arts and Humanities (GHUM), or Science and Technology (GSCI). Failed or dropped courses must be made up before graduation.

Students can make up these classes during the day, and some are offered in the evening through Continuing Education. It is important to check with the business office staff to ensure that Continuing Education courses are equivalent to those taught in the full-time program. Not all courses may be offered every semester. Students with special timetable requirements should consult the business office for assistance.

The following is a list of courses offered during Semesters 1, 2, and 3:

Semester 1:
- BUS 1038 (Business Concepts I)
- COMM 2000 (Communicating Across Contexts)
- COMP 1010 (Business Computer Applications I)
- HRM 1008 (Fundamentals of HR Management)
- MARK 1020 (Principles of Marketing I)
- MATH 1008 (Math for Business & Management I)

Semester 2:
- ACCT 1036 (Principles of Accounting)
- BUS 1040 (Project Management)
- COMM 1034 (Professional Communications I)
- COMP 1115 (Business Computer Applications II)
- MATH 1095 (Math for Business & Management II)
- MATH 1008 (Math for Business & Management I)
- PSY 1129 (Organizational Behaviour)

Semester 3:
- ECON 1032 (Macroeconomics)
- MARK 1002 (Professional Selling)
- MGMT 4009 (Operations Management)
- MATH 1008 (Math for Business & Management I)
- MGMT 1035 (Global Trade Assessment)
- MARK 1020 (Principles of Marketing II)
- STAT 1012 (Business Statistics)
- CMMK 1087 (Human Skills)

Context:
The graduate of this program is expected to be able to:
1. Evaluate the impact of global issues on an organization using an environmental scan.
2. Apply principles of corporate sustainability, social responsibility, and ethics to support business initiatives.
3. Assess and use current concepts, systems, and technologies for business initiatives.
4. Conduct and present research to support decision-making.
5. Plan, implement, and evaluate projects using project management principles.
6. Perform work in compliance with relevant statutes, regulations, and business practices.
7. Apply human resource practices to support management objectives and organizational goals.
8. Use accounting and financial principles to support the management and operations of an organization.
9. Assess marketing and sales concepts and strategies for organizational needs.
10. Outline principles of supply chain management and operations management.
11. Participate in the development of a business plan.
12. Develop strategies for ongoing personal and professional development.
13. Outline strategies used to manage risks in an organization's business activities.

Tuition & Fees:
Domestic Tuition (Fall 2022): $4,663.00
International Tuition (Fall 2023): $17,455.00

Additional Costs:
The amounts listed are for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 2022 and Fall 2023, respectively. Fees are subject to change for later program starts.

Financial Assistance:
This program is approved for OSAP funding, provided the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements:
Applicants must have an Ontario Secondary School Diploma or equivalent and a grade 12 English (C or U) and grade 11 math.

Context:
* Secondary School Diploma or equivalent is required for application.
* Minimum grade requirements: grade 12 English (C or U), grade 11 math (C, M or U) or grade 12 (C or U).
* Mature students (aged 19 or older and without OSSD) can take the Admissions Assessment for English and math, or upgrade to achieve necessary credits.
* Some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions.
* English language proficiency is necessary.
* Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, international students through George Brown Online Application System.
* Information sessions held regularly, sign up for an upcoming session.
* Contact Admissions Office for domestic inquiries (admissions@georgebrown.ca), International recruitment representatives for international inquiries (International Contact Us page).
* For financial aid inquiries, contact Financial Aid Office (FinAid@georgebrown.ca) or visit the Financial Aid section.
* Entry advising available for advice on program options.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Business Administration Program B145 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Programs and Contacts:

1. For general advising and program inquiries, contact the Entry Advisor or visit their FAQ section.
2. Centre for Business: Contact via email (business@georgebrown.ca) or phone ((416) 415-5000 ext. 2160). For specific program-related inquiries, contact Mario Pascucci (mpascucc@georgebrown.ca).
3. International students: Contact international recruitment representatives through the "International Contact Us" page or by booking a virtual meeting.
4. Programs offered: Business Administration (B145/155), Business Administration with work experience (B155), and International Business Management (Postgraduate) (B411).
5. Campus locations: Classes primarily take place at the St. James Campus, specifically 200 King St. E., and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Tours are available to sign up for.
6. Contact methods: Book a campus tour or info session, or sign up to receive tailored resources.
7. Social media: Follow the Centre for Business on Instagram and LinkedIn.
